messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] mantus fittings
messages.msgSnippet: Richard. thank you for the link.  I am aware of that one, the kozuka is self described as a reproduction, and truthfully, I am almost positive that the menuki
messages.messageBody:
Richard.

thank you for the link. I am aware of that one, the kozuka is self described as a reproduction, and truthfully, I am almost positive that the menuki are repros also. so I would be looking just at the tsuba (which I do want), but unfortunately, with the euro being so expensive, it is too much money. Still you never know so I appreciate the heads up. all the best.
Ken

This is for the mantus guy. I found the following set of mantus fittings
when I was surfing the web
The set is about halfway down the page on the left. #124

http://www.juwelier-strebel.de/Asien/Japan/Tsubas.htm

Rich H

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Looking for help to ID a tsuba...
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, I would add without a doubt to what Richard said. Better than it being a treasure that didn t get good care, honestly. Ron STL ... From: Richard Turner
messages.messageBody:
Yes, I would add "without a doubt" to what Richard said. Better than it being a treasure that didn't get good care, honestly.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, September 21, 2008 5:12 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Looking for help to ID a tsuba...


Hi AW, welcome. Yes I think this is a Repo also, but maybe late 20th
century as a guess. It's a copy, I believe of a Kô Shôami tsuba that was
originally done in a soft metal (Yamagane from memory) in the Momoyama
period, or perhaps a bit earlier.

Anyway. as I said, I think this is a very modern repo, just my opinioon
nayway.

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Looking for help to ID a tsuba...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi AW, welcome. Yes I think this is a Repo also, but maybe late 20th century as a guess. It s a copy, I believe of a Kô Shôami tsuba that was originally done
messages.messageBody:
Hi AW, welcome. Yes I think this is a Repo also, but maybe late 20th
century as a guess. It's a copy, I believe of a Kô Shôami tsuba that was
originally done in a soft metal (Yamagane from memory) in the Momoyama
period, or perhaps a bit earlier.

Anyway. as I said, I think this is a very modern repo, just my opinioon
nayway.

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Looking for help to ID a tsuba...
messages.msgSnippet: I ve had this tsuba for well over 20 years, & have wondered what info there might be on it... It s a rabbit & waves design, with no ID marks. It s iron, about
messages.messageBody:
I've had this tsuba for well over 20 years, & have wondered what info
there might be on it... It's a rabbit & waves design, with no ID marks.
It's iron, about 8cm x 8.5cm x 4mm. I believe it's a early 20th
cent. repro, at least I kind of hope it is, as it's been on several of
my practice swords over the years... When I got it it had a nice solid
brown patina, but enough rust scaling to need cleaning with a wirewheel.

Pics are here-
http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/e85a

Any thoughts would be greatly appreciated. Not looking to sell it,
just info on period, school, maker, etc... :)

Thanks!

A.W.
